title: Obama's Plan B: Engage with the Republicans
authors: Carrie Budoff Brown, Glenn Thrush, Manu Raju
content:
Obama invited a handful of ostensibly persuadable Republican senators to dinner . | AP Photos Obama 's Plan B : Engage with GOP
President Barack Obama ’ s outside game just headed indoors , on account of inclement political weather .
Since he defeated Mitt Romney four months ago , the president and his team have touted his capacity to shape the debate on budget , taxes and entitlements by barnstorming around the country to batter Hill Republicans as a bunch of do-nothing radicals intent on wrecking the economy .
But the Obama brand that won him two presidential elections — that he ’ s the only reasonable grown-up willing to make deals in the interest of the greater good — has clearly taken a hit as voters sour on his new , post-election bellicosity .
While the White House is still intent on hammering House Republicans they view as unreachable , Obama increasingly sees a path out of gridlock through the Senate GOP conference , whose members want to prove their party is capable of big , meaningful bipartisan deals that belie the “ Party of No ” label , Democrats tell ███ .
That ’ s why Obama invited some ostensibly persuadable Republican senators over to the Jefferson Hotel near the White House for dinner Wednesday — a list of invitees that includes on-again , off-again adversaries like John McCain ( R-Ariz. ) , Lindsey Graham ( R-S.C. ) , Ron Johnson ( R-Wis. ) , Kelly Ayotte ( R-N.H. ) , Rob Portman ( R-Ohio ) and Pat Toomey ( R-Pa. ) .
It will be part of a “ series ” of sit-downs he plans with the opposition , according to one West Wing official .
The idea for the get-together was first discussed last week at a White House meeting between McCain , Graham and Obama , aides say .
“ The Speaker couldn ’ t deliver his conference in past negotiations and plenty of House Republicans have made clear they ’ re comfortable losing public opinion battles — but there might be a third way — [ Senate ] Republicans who realize there ’ s both a policy necessity and political benefit to reaching a deal , ” said Ben LaBolt , a longtime Obama adviser who served as national press secretary on the 2012 reelection campaign .
A top Senate Republican leadership aide told ███ : “ Essentially he is at a dead end . He can ’ t undo sequester or touch taxes without a big deal that reforms entitlements… He did a national campaign-style campaign on the sequester and it didn ’ t really move the needle and his numbers dropped a bit . ”
“ I think it ’ s very helpful for the president to reach out to members and spend time with them , ” said Maine ’ s Susan Collins , one of the most moderate Republican senators , but who ’ s not on Wednesday ’ s guest list . “ That ’ s not something he ’ s done much of and I think this kind of initiative is overdue but very welcome none the less . I did have a good discussion with the president on Monday .
It represents an abrupt switch from the combative tone adopted by Obama and his staff since the election . In background briefings with reporters , White House officials have mocked calls by pundits for face-to-face talks , arguing that the only way to deal with recalcitrant GOP legislators was to leverage public opinion against them — in what one Democratic surrogate referred to as the “ Barack and hard place ” strategy .
CORRECTION : Corrected by : Nick Gass @ 03/06/2013 08:45 PM CORRECTION : An earlier version of this article stated that Sen. Blunt had been invited to Wednesday ’ s dinner , but he was not . The article also misstated when Sen. Thune is up for re-election . He is up in 2016 .
